title: Americano Shandy Recipe
description: In the Americano Shandy recipe, a hoppy lager lends extra depth to the classic combo of bitter Campari and sweet vermouth. This recipe makes 2 cocktails.
mixologist: Reprinted with permission from Aperitif: A Spirited Guide to the Drinks, History and Culture of the Aperitif, by Kate Hawkings. Published by Quadrille September 2018.
instructions: Divide the Campari and vermouth between 2 glasses. Add ice and top up each glass with the beer, stirring gently to mix.

title: Aperitif Cocktail: Three Sunsets
description: To mimic the reds and pinks of a summer sunset, this low-proof aperitif cocktail combines red Campari with the russet hue of Cocchi di Torino and soft pink rosé.
instructions: Add all the ingredients except rosé to a shaker with ice. Shake and then double strain into glass over fresh ice. Top with 2, oz., of brut sparkling rosé and garnish.

title: Barrel Colada Cocktail
description: The Piña Colada cocktail gets a modern twist with barrel-aged gin and a banana coconut syrup at Watershed Distillery's Kitchen and Bar in Columbus, Ohio.
mixologist: Josh Gandee, Watershed Kitchen and Bar, Columbus, Ohio
instructions: Combine all ingredients in a shaker tin and shake to chill. Strain over crushed ice. Garnish with a mint bouquet and dehydrated banana.

title: Basil Cocktail from Pobrecito
description: In this cocktail from Pobrecito, fresh bell pepper and citrus create a bright baseline for vodka and Chartreuse.
instructions: Muddle 2 basil leaves in a shaker tin. Add the remaining ingredients and ice. Shake until chilled. Fine strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube. Garnish.

title: Beer Cocktail: Jealous Moon
description: Italian liqueurs take center stage in this beer cocktail, which is topped with a splash of pale ale. Coltivare uses Deschutes Mirror Pond Pale Ale.
instructions: Combine all the ingredients except the beer in a shaker and shake with ice to chill. Strain into a snifter filled with large ice cubes. Top with beer; garnish.

title: Bitter Giuseppe Cocktail
description: A modern classic with Cynar, sweet vermouth, lemon and orange bitters.
mixologist: Stephen Cole, The Violet Hour, Chicago
instructions: Stir all the ingredients together in a mixing glass with ice until chilled. Strain into a rocks glass over a single large ice cube and garnish.

title: Calimocho Cocktail
description: A simple stir of red wine and cola, the Calimocho (or Kalimoxto), is a summer classic in Spain. Inexpensive, dry red wine works well (like Grenache or Shiraz), and Booze and Vinyl authors André Darlington & Tenaya Darlington suggest lemon-lime soda for a twist. Pair it with their Summer Grill + Chill playlist.
mixologist: Reprinted with permission from Booze & Vinyl: A Spirited Guide to Great Music and Mixed Drinks, © 2018 by André Darlington & Tenaya Darlington, Running Press.
instructions: Combine the wine and cola in cups filled with ice. Give it a quick stir. Garnish.

title: Whiskey Champagne Punch
description: It's finally patio season, and The Dawson in Chicago recently rolled out a long list of refreshing punches fit for the occasion. The Champagne Whiskey Punch presents a blend of tart raspberries and bright lemon that helps temper the oak and vanilla flavors of the whiskey. Champagne brings a snappy punch of bubbles to the mix. Batch one up for your next patio party.
instructions: Combine the whiskey, lemon, bitters and syrups together in a punch bowl over a large ice cube and stir until ingredients are integrated. Top with sparkling wine. No garnish. Serves 6-8.

title: Classic Hot Toddy
description: The ultimate winter warmer.
garnish: half lemon wheel studded with cloves
instructions:
Preheat a tempered mug, then add the hot water, Irish whiskey, and honey syrup. Garnish. 
*Meehan makes a slightly richer syrup using two-thirds honey to one-third water, but he says sweetening with sugar, agave or maple syrup works just as well.

title: Apple Brandy Cocktail: Concrete Slippers
mixologist: David Ruiz, at Junior in San Francisco
description: For this cocktail from Junior in San Francisco, owner David Ruiz mixes warming apple brandy with spicy ancho chile. “The ancho provides depth and warmth and plays perfectly with the ginger and the apple brandy,” says Ruiz.
instructions: Combine all of the ingredients in a shaker with ice. Shake until chilled, then strain into a Collins glass over ice (Ruiz uses pebble ice at the bar).

title: Corpse Reviver No. Blue
description: Back in 2007, Jacob Briars introduced this cheeky homage to the Corpse Reviver No. 2 with blue curaçao instead of Cointreau. “It tastes broadly and very much like a classic cocktail from the 1920s and '30s—it just happens to be blue,” Briars says. He usually reaches for a blue bottle of Bombay Sapphire gin to seal the deal.
instructions: Shake ingredients with ice to chill, then fine strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish.

title: Deep South Cocktail
description: Mezcal infused peaches add a summery spin to this whiskey sour from Houston bartender Sean Beck.
instructions: In a shaker, combine all ingredients with ice and shake well. Fine strain into an Old Fashioned glass over a large ice cube and garnish with the lemon and peach slices.

title: Mezcal Cocktail: DJ Lisa
mixologist: Alex Maynard, Starline Social Club, Oakland, California
description: In this mezcal cocktail from Starline Social Club, the agave spirit finds a perfect flavor match in citrus and cinnamon.
instructions: Shake all the ingredients with ice and strain into an ice-filled glass. Garnish.

title: Dunderstruck Rum Cocktail
description: Bitter Campari and rich Jamaican rum play with a fruity symphony of pineapple and strawberry in this recipe from The Public House.
mixologist: Matthew Roedel, The Public House, Bay City, Michigan

ingredients.name: Jamaican Rum (Public House uses Two James Doctor Bird)

instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice. Strain into a rocks glass with one large cube. Garnish.

title: El Presidente Variation: Walter Mondale
description: This cocktail named for the former Minnesota senator and Vice President started as a variation on the classic El Presidente, with apple brandy and pear liqueur offering an extra layer of midwestern flavor.

ingredients.name: apple brandy (Young Joni uses Laird's Bonded)

instructions: Stir all ingredients with ice to chill, and strain into a chilled glass. Garnish.

title: Everyday Superhero: A Blackberry Smash
description: The richness of brandy and merlot meet the bright pop of fresh lime and berries in this stunning blackberry smash.
instructions: In a rocks glass, muddle the berries. Combine all of the other ingredients in a shaker with ice and shake vigorously. Add ice to the rocks glass, then strain the shaker ingredients into the glass and stir to combine. Garnish.

ingredients.name: brandy
ingredients.description: (ALEX&NDER uses Copper & Kings American Craft Aged Brandy)

title: Fisher's Mezcal Old Fashioned
description: For his take on the Mezcal Old Fashioned, bartender Mauro Fisher sought to achieve complex flavors using an uncomplicated formula. On the cocktail menu at Sawyer in Seattle, a 2019 James Beard semifinalist for Best New Restaurant, the Fisher's Fashioned seamlessly blends mezcal with a time-tested Italian amaro.
instructions: Stir all the ingredients with ice to chill then strain into rocks glass over a large ice cube and garnish.

title: GreenRiver Cocktail: Time Release
description: Something a little different for gin drinkers, this complex cocktail is anchored by a juniper-forward gin, while yellow Chartreuse adds an herbaceous edge and sloe gin and white port lend fruity layers. “This is a stirred drink served up, so after time it will warm up a bit,” says former GreenRiver beverage director Julia Momose. “The ingredients taste very different when cold than when at room temperature, so the name plays off that idea. It'll change as you drink it.”
instructions: Combine ingredients in a mixing glass with ice. Stir until chilled and strain into a Nick and Nora glass. Garnish.

title: Harvard Sour
description: The warming notes of Sfumato Rabarbaro, applejack, Armagnac and spiced pumpkin syrup lend an autumnal edge to this cocktail. “I was looking to create a fall cocktail that had Massachusetts written all over it,” says Ned King of Amherst Coffee + Bar. “Something that made you think of picking apples and carving pumpkins. The name comes from Harvard Forest in Petersham, Massachusetts, and it's only a few miles from where I grew up. It's owned by Harvard University and is one of America's oldest managed forests.”
mixologist: Ned King, Amherst Coffee + Bar, Amherst, Massachusetts
instructions: Combine all the ingredients in a shaker and dry shake to emulsify egg white. Add ice to the shaker tin and shake until chilled. Strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a sprinkle of cinnamon in the center of the cocktail.

title: Prickly Pear Cocktail: Hearts & Minds
description: With a name meant to evoke the unspoken mysteries of faraway places, this sparkling cocktail from Liberty in Seattle is a study in opposing flavors. “Agricole was a natural fit, with the lighter-bodied tropical notes balancing and counter playing the dry and bitter fernet,” says bartender Andrew Dalan.
instructions: Shake the rhum agricole, lemon, purée and syrup in a shaker tin with ice. Strain into a chilled flute and top with the sparkling wine. Float the Fernet on top of wine using the back of a barspoon

title: I'm Old Fashioned
description: Jungle Bird owner Krissy Harris found inspiration for this Old Fashioned riff in the tropical food and drink trends of the 1950s. “On many dishes from this time period, a maraschino cherry and ring of canned pineapple were the garnish, so I thought to split the rye base with Stiggin's Fancy Pineapple Rum and replace the sugar cube with maraschino liqueur. Instead of the classic Angostura bitters, which I felt would overpower the tropical notes, I used Punt e Mes vermouth for a more balanced flavor.”
garnish: maraschino cherry and pineapple cube soaked with Angostura bitters
instructions: Combine all of the ingredients in a mixing glass with ice, then stir for at least 20 seconds. Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice, then garnish.

title: Landing Gear Fizz Falernum Cocktail
description: Delightfully low-proof, this falernum cocktail blends clove and cinnamon flavors with the bold, bitter notes of Punt e Mes. Mint and lime elevate everything into dangerously refreshing territory.
instructions: In a shaker, combine all ingredients except soda water. Shake with ice to chill. Strain into an ice-filled Collins glass, top with soda water and garnish.

title: Low-ABV Cocktail: Floppy Disk
description: This low-ABV cocktail gets a boost of flavor from mezcal and Cynar.
mixologist: Jenner Cormier, Bar Kismet, Halifax, Nova Scotia
instructions: Combine the first 4 ingredients with ice and shake to chill. Add the soda to an ice-filled glass, then strain into the glass. Garnish.

title: Lux Princess From Coltivare Houston
description: Almonds and coconut combine with fresh mint in this delicious zero-proof recipe from Coltivare Houston.
instructions: Add the first 6 ingredients to a shaker with ice, then shake to chill. Strain into a glass filled with crushed ice, then top with the sparkling water. Garnish with mint and cherries, and dust powdered sugar on top.

title: Mary Astor, A Gin Sour
description: Bright and botanical, this gin-based sour gets an extra flavor boost from sherry and sloe gin.
mixologist: Church Cummings, Josephine Estelle at the Ace Hotel, New Orleans
instructions: Shake the ingredients together in a shaker with ice. Double strain into a chilled coupe, then garnish with an expressed lemon peel.

title: Moi Vermouth Cocktail
description: The prominent piney notes of a juniper-forward gin keep the spirit's character at the forefront of this vermouth cocktail, even though it's used in small amounts.
mixologist: Sean Sullivan for Straight Law, Boston
instructions: Combine the first 4 ingredients in a shaker and shake with ice to chill. Strain into glass filled with fresh ice; top with chilled tonic.

title: Naked in the Desert: A Sotol Cocktail
description: In his nod to Joaquín Simó's Naked and Famous cocktail, Diego Valencia skips the mezcal and brings in another Mexican spirit, sotol. The result is an extra earthy interpretation of the original.
garnish: grapefruit twist, six drops of Angostura bitters
instructions: Add all the ingredients to a shaker with ice. Shake well and strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice. Garnish.

title: No. 2 Fleet Street, A Gin Cocktail
description: Designed to highlight the floral, herbaceous character of a contemporary gin, this cocktail accents these flavors with pineapple, coffee and Chartreuse.
instructions: Shake all the ingredients with ice to chill, then double strain into a chilled glass and garnish.

title: Oaxaca Old Fashioned
description: The New York bar Mayahuel has introduced countless drinkers to the joys of agave spirits, and this Oaxaca Old Fashioned—created by Phil Ward when he worked at Death & Co.—mixes reposado tequila with mezcal and the chocolate-spice notes of mole bitters to create a lovely riff on the classic.

ingredients.name: mezcal
ingredients.description: (Del Maguey Chichicapa or San Luis del Rio)

instructions: Combine all the ingredients except the orange twist in an Old Fashioned glass filled with one large ice cube. Stir until chilled. To top with a flamed orange twist, carefully hold a piece of orange peel about the size of a silver dollar, skin side down, over the drink. Light a match and use it to warm the skin side of the peel. Holding the match a few inches above the drink, quickly squeeze the peel in the direction of the match. The oil from the peel will briefly ignite, landing over the drink's surface.

title: Paloma Riff: Tasteful Nudes
description: Referencing both the classic Paloma cocktail and the Indian Paintbrush from Garage bar in Austin, the Tasteful Nudes is a prime example of Matthew Roedel's mixing prowess. “I love the grapefruit/rosemary combination and thought that adding tequila to the mix would make for something quintessentially Southwestern,” he says of the drink. “Toasting the rosemary added a pleasant smokiness as well offering a striking visual presentation. From there, I thought the Aperol was a great way to marry the citrus-y/sweet elements of the drink to the bitter, vegetal aspects of the agave and the aromatics.”
mixologist: Matthew Roedel, The Public House, Bay City, Michigan
instructions: Add all the ingredients except the rosemary to a shaker, shake and strain into an ice-filled collins glass. Toast the rosemary sprig with a kitchen torch until smoldering and place into the glass to garnish.

title: Paloma Riff: Red Macaw Cocktail
mixologist: Jason Stevens, Boiler Nine Bar & Grill, Austin
description: From the Booze Your Own Adventure menu at Boiler Nine in Austin, this refreshing highball was inspired by the flavor intersections of the Paloma and Donga Punch, a tiki cocktail discovered by Jeff “Beachbum” Berry made with rhum, Don's mix and lime juice. “The flavors in the Red Macaw naturally pair with tequila and light rum, but each base spirit creates a uniquely different, delicious cocktail,” says beverage director Jason Stevens. Mezcal, aged rum, gin and grappa also work well.

ingredients.name: base spirit (Stevens suggests blanco tequila, rhum agricole, vodka)

instructions: Build all ingredients in a tall glass. Stir briefly to mix. Top with crushed ice. Garnish.

title: Hibiscus Concentrate
description: Concentrated Hibiscus tea, with a touch of cinnamon flavor
instructions: Combine all ingredients and let steep for 24-48 hours. Strain out solids and bottle. Yields 12 oz., Lasts for 6 months.

title: River Styx from Kindred San Diego
description: The bittersweet notes of coffee and chocolate liqueurs play off the richness of bourbon and allspice dram in this cocktail from Kindred San Diego.
instructions: Combine all the ingredients in an Old Fashioned glass, add ice and stir. Garnish.

title: Rye Cocktail from Meauxbar
description: Fresh lime juice and banana liqueur perk up this rye cocktail from Meauxbar in New Orleans.
instructions: Shake all the ingredients together in a mixing tin with ice. Strain into a chilled coupe.

title: Saturn's Return from King Tai Bar
description: In this glass of tropical sunshine, coconut water and passion fruit meet herbaceous gin and a bittersweet aperitivo.
instructions: Combine ingredients in a shaker tin with ice and shake. Strain into a footed tulip glass over fresh ice and garnish with a lemon wheel.

title: Session Cocktail: Franco-Italian Swizzle
description: Inspired by ingredients from both sides of the Franco-Italian border, this low-proof refresher from Steven Robbins of Half Step in Austin is perfect for quenching thirst.
mixologist: Reprinted with permission from Session Cocktails: Low-Alcohol Drinks for Any Occasion by Drew Lazor and the Editors of PUNCH, copyright © 2018. Published by Ten Speed Press, an imprint of Penguin Random House.”
instructions: Combine the Cocchi, lemon juice, and Chartreuse in a Collins glass, then top with the soda water. Add crushed ice and swizzle to mix, then garnish.

title: Alex Negranza's Slick Watts
description: Houston bartender (and 2018 Bartender of the Year) Alex Negranza—who moved to the city from Seattle—named this drink for fellow transplant Slick Watts, an NBA point guard who played for the Seattle Supersonics from 1973 to 1978 before moving to Texas to play for the Houston Rockets.
instructions: Stir all of the ingredients with ice to chill, strain into an ice-filled glass, then garnish.

title: Sloe and Unsteady
description: Much to the surprise of bartender Jessica Sanders, this tart and tangy sloe gin cocktail turned out to be a best-seller on the winter menu.
instructions: Shake all ingredients with ice to chill. Fine strain into a chilled coupe and garnish.

title: Strawberry Cocktail: Seven Year Itch
description: Sparkling wine gives this strawberry cocktail some extra pep.
mixologist: Ruben M. Chavez, 3Eleven Kitchen & Cocktails, Dallas
instructions: Muddle the strawberries in a mixing glass and add the elderflower liqueur, vodka and lemon. Shake with ice until chilled. Strain the mixture into a chilled glass with fresh ice. Top with sparkling wine and garnish.

title: Strawberry-Infused Vodka
description: I might make this double, this wound up being really popular
instructions: Remove stems from about 30 strawberries, and cut them into quarters. Fill one quart-sized canning jar with the berries and add 1/4 cup brown sugar to jar. Fill jar with vodka, cover lid and shake. Then, put canning jar in the fridge for approximately 2 days. Once the mixture turns pink after a couple of days, strain vodka and toss the berries. For more strawberry flavor, repeat steps 1 – 5

title: Highball: The Candice
description: Equal parts sweet, tart and floral, this summery highball is a keeper.
instructions: Combine the first 5 ingredients in a shaker tin with ice. Shake until chilled. Fill a Collins glass with fresh ice and strain contents of mixing tin into the glass. Top with club soda. Garnish.

title: The Watermelon Cooler From Best Intentions
description: Real watermelon doesn't make an appearance in this ultra-refreshing cooler from Best Intentions in Chicago, but the combination of Aperol, cucumber vodka and fino sherry do a great job of mimicking the juicy fruit's flavor.
mixologist: Andrew Prazich & Calvin Marty, Best Intentions, Chicago
instructions: Shake all the ingredients together in a mixing tin with ice. Pour over fresh ice cubes in a Collins glass. Garnished with fresh mint, lightly tapped on the back of the hand to release the aromatics.

title: Rye Whiskey Cocktail: To the Point
description: Upgrade your next tea time with this mix of rye whiskey, Chartreuse and Earl Grey tea syrup.
instructions: Add the whiskey, Chartreuse and syrup to mixing glass with ice. Stir to chill, then strain over ice in a rocks glass. Grate cinnamon over the orange peel or orange rose. To make an orange rose: Peel 1 orange, then wrap the orange peel into a circle, starting with the thinnest peel as the center of the rose. Poke with cocktail pick, then insert a clove or cocktail pick to keep the rose together.

title: Toronto Sour from Prairie School
description: At Jim Meehan's Chicago bar Prairie School (now closed), the New York Sour gets some Canadian flavor with the addition of rye whiskey and maple syrup.
instructions: Shake the whiskey, lemon juice and maple syrup in a shaker tin with ice. Strain into a chilled coupe. Float the Malbec on top of the drink.

title: Wine Cocktail: Peacock Buck
description: A fruity Spanish rosé sets an easygoing tone for this refreshing wine cocktail.
mixologist: Nicolas Bennett, Cedric's at The Shed, New York City
instructions: Shake all the ingredients together with ice and fine strain into a wine glass over pebble ice. Top with soda.

title: Whiskey Passion Cocktail
description: The Whiskey Sour gets some tropical warmth in this cocktail from Bordel in Chicago. 'Subtle tart citrusy notes from the passion fruit round out with rye and vanilla flavors,' says bar manager Ricky Alvarado.
garnish: dehydrated (or fresh) lemon wheel, fresh rosemary sprig
instructions: Add all of the ingredients to a shaker with ice. Shake to chill, then fine strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice. Garnish.

title: Ebenezer Scrooge Spritz
description: The bittersweetness of Cynar mixes with the spice of ginger, the pop of lemon juice and the fizz of sparkling wine in this festive spritz.
instructions: Combine the Cynar, ginger liqueur, lemon juice, brown sugar and bitters in a shaker. Add ice and shake well. Strain into a chilled flute, top with the sparkling wine, then garnish.

title: Jack's Rose Cocktail
description: At Watershed Kitchen & Bar, this riff on the classic Jack Rose is made with the distillery's own bourbon and apple brandy.
mixologist: Josh Gandee, Watershed Kitchen & Bar, Columbus
instructions: Shake the first 4 ingredients with ice, then strain into a chilled coupe and top with cider.

title: Mulled Wine Recipe
description: Warming cocktails are perfect for transitioning into the fall and winter months, yet in the United States we've all but forgotten Europe's oldest hot drink: mulled wine. “Mulled,” in this context, means heated and spiced; if you want to make it sound more exotic, call it by its medieval name, hypocras; folks thought it did a body good—so much so that they named it after Hippocrates, the ancient Greek father of medicine.
mixologist: Wrap the spices and citrus zest in a large piece of cheesecloth, approximately 12 inches square, tying a knot to seal the bundle. Place the spice sack in non-reactive pot. Pour the wine into the pot and add the brandy. Simmer over low heat, stirring occasionally. When the mixture is warm, stir in the sugar, syrup or honey. Don't let the mulled wine boil, or you risk cooking out the flavors. Leave over low heat for about 30 minutes while the flavors meld. Continue stirring occasionally. When the liquid is steaming lightly, it is ready to serve. Ladle into warm mugs. Have lemon wedges and extra sugar on hand so guests can squeeze in extra acidity if they want to cut the sweetness or add more sugar to indulge a sweet tooth. Note: Adjust ingredients and proportions to personal taste, but don't let the sweetness overwhelm the wine's acidity or the drink will be cloying.
instructions: Like sangria in summer, mulled wine enhances the fruit of the vine with a wintry combination of spices, fruit, brandy and sugar. Think of it as liquid fruitcake, except that your guests will actually be glad to see it when the holidays roll around. It's an easy alternative to the common spiced cider, and it's a great way to breathe new life into a stale bottle of wine.

ingredients.name: Zest of half an orange or lemon
brown sugar (maple syrup or honey is a great substitution)

title: The Brown Turkey
description: One bite of savory fig stuffing served at a holiday feast and Justin Chamberlin knew he'd found his next cocktail inspiration. This Thanksgiving cocktail combines the subtle spices of aged rum with the sultry sweetness of figs and a bright pop of sparkling wine.
mixologist: Justin L. Chamberlin, Sagra Trattoria and Bar, Austin, Texas
instructions: Combine all ingredients, except sparkling wine, and shake with ice to chill. Fine-strain into a chilled flute, top with sparkling wine and garnish.

title: The Peppermint Dandy Cocktail
description: “Winter always makes me want a cream-based cocktail or the warm vibes of a minty hot chocolate, so I figured why not combine them in a Grasshopper variation?” asks Fabien Piccoli, beverage director at Antica Pesa in Brooklyn.
instructions: Rim half the glass with simple syrup and coat with crushed peppermint candies. In a shaker, add all of the ingredients with ice and shake well. Strain into the rimmed glass.

title: Rhubarb-Ginger Planter's Punch
description: Planter's Punch, the tiki classic with Caribbean origins, has sparked countless riffs over the years. Here, photographer and recipe developer Eva Kosmas Flores gives the drink a seasonal twist with the inclusion of rhubarb-ginger syrup in place of grenadine.
mixologist: Reprinted with permission from First We Eat: Good Food for Simple Gatherings from My Pacific Northwest Kitchen by Eva Kosmas Flores, copyright 2018. Published by Abrams.
instructions: In a large pitcher, stir together the pineapple juice, rum, lime juice, syrup and the rhubarb slices. Distribute among four ice-filled glasses and serve. Serves 4.

title: Hibiscus Tea Cobbler
description: ibiscus tea lends a floral edge to this Cognac-based cobbler. Instead of shaking the drink, Bar Casa Vale bar manager Daniel Parker Guidry treats the recipe more like a swizzle. “It makes for a more potent and refreshing version of the drink,” he says.
mixologist: Daniel Parker Guidry, Bar Casa Vale, Portland, Oregon
instructions:
In a Collins glass, combine the grenadine and lemon wheel and muddle until the oils from the citrus are released into the syrup. Add the curaçao, cognac and hibiscus tea, then fill with crushed ice. Stir until the cocktail starts to dilute, then add more ice and garnish. 
 Hibiscus Tea: Pour 4¼ cups of boiling water over 3½ oz. of dried hibiscus flowers, steep for 10 minutes, strain through cheese cloth and bottle.
garnish: lemon wheel, hibiscus flowers, Amarena cherry

title: Vanilla Syrup
description: Classic flavored simple syrup
instructions: Combine simple syrup with vanilla extract. Shake to combine and refrigerate for up to 2 weeks.

title: Fig and Brown Sugar Reduction
description: For the Brown Turkey cocktail
instructions: Combine water and brown sugar in a saucepan over medium-high heat and stir to dissolve sugar. Add figs, and bring to a boil. Cover, remove from heat and let steep for 25 minutes. Fine-strain into a glass bottle and refrigerate for up to 2 weeks.

ingredients.name: chopped fresh figs
ingredients.description: (Chamberlin uses Brown Turkeys, but feel free to substitute any variety)

title: Rhubarb-Ginger syrup
description: For the Planter's Punch
instructions: In a small saucepan, combine rhubarb stalks, ginger, sugar and water. Bring to a boil over medium high heat. Reduce the heat to low and cook until the rhubarb has nearly disintegrated and the ginger has softened, 10 to 15 minutes. Remove from heat and allow to cool for 5 minutes. Strain the syrup into a bowl and discard the solids.

title: Sage Syrup
description: This one has a really earthy good smell
instructions: Combine sugar with water in a saucepan over medium heat, stirring until the sugar is dissolved. Remove from heat and allow to cool to room temperature. Add sage leaves and let sit for 24 hours. Strain out the leaves and bottle for use. Refrigerate for up to 2 weeks.

title: Banana Coconut Syrup
description: The coconut that you'll have left over, tastes like an unbaked macaron ::chef's kiss::
instructions: Toast coconut flakes until fragrant, then add coconut milk and white sugar. Stir until dissolved and strain out the solids. Add liqueur and shake to combine.

title: Mezcal Peach Syrup
description: needs description

ingredients.name: light agave nectar or simple syrup (1:1)

instructions: Remove pits and cut the peaches into half-inch cubes. Pour the mezcal into a saucepan and carefully burn off some of the alcohol (takes about 1 minute). Add the peaches and the simple syrup or agave nectar. (For extra spice, an optional .25 teaspoon of chili powder can be added). Bring to a boil over medium-high heat for 5 minutes, then reduce to a simmer for another 15 minutes. Remove from heat and let cool. Add the mixture to a blender and purée with the peach nectar until smooth. Keep refrigerated for up to 1 week.  Makes about 12 oz.

title: Strawberry Syrup
description: needs description
instructions: Cut up strawberries and combine them with sugar. Lightly crush the strawberries to express them into the sugar. Let the mixture sit for 24 hours then combine with 1 quart of hot water. Stir the mixture until it has dissolved, then strain it into a container.

title: Spiced Pumpkin Syrup
description: needs description
instructions: Combine all the ingredients in a saucepan over medium heat, stir until combined. Once the mixture starts to boil, reduce heat to medium/low and let simmer for 3 min. Remove from heat and let cool. Strain the liquid into a bottle and store in a lidded container in the refrigerator.

title: Salt tincture
description: needs description
instructions: Combine and shake until salt is dissolved.

title: Rosemary Syrup
description: needs description
instructions: Place large sprigs of rosemary in a heat-proof quart container. Cover with hot water. Let sit for 15-20 minutes. Remove the rosemary and add 2 cups of granulated sugar. Stir until fully dissolved. Fine-strain into a clean glass bottle or jar and refrigerate for up to 2 weeks.

title: Earl Grey tea syrup
description: needs description
instructions: Brew tea. Once ready, pour into a pot on low heat, add sugar and stir on low heat until dissolved. Once cooled, transfer into a bottle and refrigerate for up to 2 weeks.

title: Raspberry Syrup
description: needs description
instructions: Stir sugar and water over low heat until sugar has dissolved. Add raspberries stirring until the berries form a pulp. Strain into a jar and refrigerate. Over time, the pectin will rise to the surface and can be skimmed off.

title: Yellow Bell Pepper Syrup
description: needs description
instructions: Juice yellow bell pepper and combine the juice in a saucepan with equal parts of white sugar. Stir over medium heat until the sugar dissolves. Remove from the heat, cool, strain into a bottle and store in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks.

title: Passion Fruit Syrup
description: needs description
instructions: Combine passion fruit concentrate with simple syrup. Shake to combine and refrigerate for up to 2 weeks.

title: Ginger Syrup
description: This ginger syrup is fantastic in cocktails, but it also makes an out-of-this-world ginger ale. To make ginger ale, simply fill an ice-filled glass a third of the way with the syrup, top with soda water and a squeeze of lime, stir and enjoy.

ingredients.name: unpeeled, washed, fresh ginger, roughly chopped

instructions: Process the ginger chunks in a food processor or blender until finely chopped. Place in a large  pot. Add the sugar and water and stir. Bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer over medium-low heat and cook for 1 hour until a rich syrup is created. Strain the syrup twice through cheesecloth or a sieve into a large bottle. Refrigerate.

title: Cinnamon Syrup
description: Add a splash of sweet heat to cocktails like the Boukman Daiquiri and The Cinnsation with this simple cinnamon syrup.
instructions: Bring all ingredients to a boil over medium heat. Reduce heat to medium-low and let simmer for 8-10 minutes until sugar has dissolved, stirring frequently. Remove from heat and let cool. Discard cinnamon sticks, strain into a clean glass jar and cover. Store refrigerated for up to 2 weeks.

title: P&P Pisco Cocktail
description: This fizzy pisco cocktail matches the floral qualities of pisco with the earthiness of Pimm's.
instructions: Combine ingredients in a shaker with ice and shake to chill. Strain into a Collins glass filled with crushed ice. Top with ginger beer and garnish.
